title: How many cases of COVID-19 will the state of Texas report for the month of April 2021?
preds: The current, including-April-30th Excel sheet count is 86,492. Obviously no way that's going to be revised up to 150,000 by any late-breaking data.
Case count through the 28th is 79,876. Even if today and tomorrow somehow each have 35,000 cases, still doesn't pass 150,000.
Maintaining a rare 100% on this forecast.  Just no sign of a surge or any other factors that might result in crossing the 150,000 threshold.
Count through the end of the 26th is 72,223, less than half the number to hit 150,000 bucket by the 30th. Anyone who's even on 1% the second bucket at this point is being ridiculous.

Still not seeing any signs of a surge in Texas.  Vaccinate rate is pretty good.  Cases of COVID appears to be on the decline.  Staying firm on less than 150,000 COVID cases reported in Texas for the month of April with certainty.  Will examine again later in the week.
TEXANS  ARE PROUD OF THIER IGNORANCE OF SCIENCE AND RIGOROUS DATA.  THEY WILL PROUDLY BURNS MASKS  AND AVOID VACCINES.

Current case count (from the Excel sheet) is 69,297 April 1-24.  Sustaining that case rate, Texas will have 86,609 cases for April.   That's a bit higher than the sustained rate was back on the 20th. However, the modest growth in cases isn't fast enough to overcome the decline in time remaining. To hit the 150,000-250,000 bucket, the next six days (25th-30th) would have to average 13,450.5 cases/day, more than four and a half times both the month-so-far and last-seven-days rate.

New cases have fallen sharply since Mar 1, now running close to 3000/day and looking stable. High intensity infection areas are also rural so low absolute population. It is a long way to 150,000 even with more aggressive variants . However, I would not dismiss the chance that Texas could pull a skunk out of the hat at the last minute.
With a daily average in the last month of around 3000 new cases/ day I cannot see any chance of these increasing beyond 250,000
Hope this doesn't come back to bite ... But a rare foreseeable covid question it seems
Few projections are as clear cut as this one.  No sign of a major surge next week in Texas.  Move to the rare 100% with a week to go.
Unless there is a major spike in cases and I mean dramatic spike, there is almost 100% going to be below 150,000.
probably safe to upgrade the 1st bin

So, current case count (from the Excel sheet) is 56,201 for April.  Sustaining that rate, Texas will have 84,302 cases for April.  To reach the 150,000-250,000 bucket, the next ten days would need to average 9,380/day from here on out, 3.3 times the current average.
TX DSHS - COVID Dashboard still trending very low for April.
Never say never but it would truly take a dramatic pickup from here to average 150K for the month

Update. Just looked at the numbers: 48,825 combined confirmed + probable cases to date for April. 2872 confirmed + probable cases/day average so far. The remainder of the month would need to *average* 7783 cases/day to exceed 150k. I can't picture that happening, even with a surge in test results being reported, as there seems to be a backlog.

The current total from the Excel sheet for the first 15 days of the month of April is 43,194 (2,879.6/day).   Even at 7,000 cases/day average for the rest of the month -- more than twice the rate so far -- the total will be in bucket 1.

Seems straightforward enough... currently Texas ~ 35K (Conf + Prob). To get to 150K, need about ~6K daily rate. Seems very unlikely. Moreover, the definition of probable cases, seems like an accounting trick, technically correct, but is designed to make a certain impression. This indicates that the likelihood of understatement is higher than likelihood of overstatement.
New plus probable cases average at about 3,000 per day - which would turn out to be less than 100,000 if trends remain the same.

So, just looking at April, we have a count of 29,443 as of this posting. So we'd need to *average* more than twice as many cases/day here on out in order to exceed bucket #1, which, accelerating from the current base, means an increase in cases to the 10,000/day level before the end of the month. I mean, physically possible, sure, but . . .

Approx. 27,740 total new confirmed cases plus 'probable' cases reported from 4/1/21 through 4/10/21 by my count. (https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83) It will require a steep increase in cases through the rest of the month (20 days) to exceed 150,000 total. An average of over 6,000 per day..
You’d need to average 5k cases a day for the rest of the month which would be a rapid turnaround. Over 250 would require 10k cases on average per day
There are only abut 3000 cases in the first week.  With no major spikes, Texas should stay under 150k for the month.

This is a tough one. Current run rate is about 82K cases per month, well below the 150 threshold. On the other hand, 38,000 people are going to baseball stadiums. But there is vaccination and warm weather.

25 days left in the question. By my count around 10,620 confirmed plus probable cases have been reported thus far in April, through 4/5/21.(https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html) As mentioned in comments below it will now require an average of about 5,575 new confirmed plus probable cases/day to exceed 150,000 for the month. That number has been exceeded only on five days over the last (nearly-) five weeks, and not at all since 3/12/21.

The highest new cases in a single day is in the 4k over the last 30 days, for example 4650 on 3/13/21. Lets say by some bizzarre fluke that, in spite of vaccines distribution, the cases matched this record day every day for April.  If you had 30 days at 4650 new cases a day the total would be 13950.  Well in the "Fewer then 150,000" category. To get to 150,000 you would need 5408 EACH DAY for the rest of the month.  A record-breaking amount, each day, after vaccines to get to even "Between 150,000 and 250,000, inclusive" let alone higher.  (if you do my math it might seem little off.  Here it is "(150000-2528-1465)/27".  The "2528-1465" accounts for the days 4/1 and 4/3 which i have data for already so would need to be removed from 150000 to get an average of the 27 remaining days.)
Average case numbers continue to drop with immunization continuing to rise, bring the expected cases in April further down to approx. 100k.
Texas surge will probably come too late for this question to be >150k. A move of  the timeframe  +-15 days would probably be sufficient.

The most recent seven-day average of new confirmed cases + 'probable' in Texas is around 3,050/day. https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html Texas still has one of the lower vaccination rates per 100,000 (https://www.kvue.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/all-adults-texas-eligible-covid-19-vaccine-appointment-sign-up-schedule-what-to-know-dallas-fort-worth-north-texas/287-38a382ac-4b67-49a7-a5b3-65c58ecbe712)

Updating again. Getting a better feel for the TX data. For 150k cases in April, need avg of ~5k/day. Right now we are at ~4k/day. I had thought we might be starting April closer to 3k/day, in which case I don't think the >150k bin would be highly probable. But we're at 4k/day with hints of an uptick. I'm not sure to what extent cases will grow now in TX, though. Weather and vaccinations/immunity are on one side of the scale, and 100% open policies and variants (esp. B.1.1.7) are on the other side. Watch and wait.

even though the statewide mask mandate has been lifted, many businesses have maintained their mask mandates. with increasing vaccination rates and availability, the current 7 day daily average of cases is ~4,000 and has been trending downward. As long as vaccine supplies are not further disrupted, Texas has an effective vaccination program and the daily rate will continue to decrease or, at worst, stay level. Vaccination rates may be offset by the more infectious COVID variants.

The total amount of new cases in March is approximately 130,000. The cases in April should be less with the declining trend of new cases since the weather is warmer and the vaccine is being prevailed.

Your numbers are multiple-factors above realistic range. The the current daily new-case count has been fewer than 3,000 for many days and the TX vaccination rate is exceeding all other states at 10 million+ doses provided
https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83
Texas is reporting about 2,000 cases a day.

The 150k threshold for bin 2 is 5k cases per day.
The 250k threshold for bin 3 is 8.3k cases per day.   Cases bottomed out about 4k per day but are now starting to creep up again, which is what we would have expected with restrictions easing.  Could stay below 5k per day across April but with Easter and the increase starting we can see that any reductions take a month or more to trail off again, so expect the rise to keep going up during April.  It’s just how far up they go.  Forecast back to bin 2 again for now. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#compare-trends_newcases
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/09/01/816707182/map-tracking-the-spread-of-the-coronavirus-in-the-u-s?t=1616627900777&t=1616800484776&t=1616888017063&t=1616970017185&t=1617145591703
TOO MANY INBREDS AND SPRING BREAKERS CONGRIGATING THERE

Significantly revising previous forecast. I think cases in TX will likely grow, but I don't think they'll grow fast enough. Even if they start growing tomorrow with a doubling rate for # cases/day of 20 days, analogous to last fall, we'll barely get to about 152.6k total. But this is a more pleasant time of year for being outside in Texas; more people go indoors for air conditioning in the summer. Cases increased in the Southwest last summer. So I suspect we won't see quite so much growth by the end of April. But it's on the edge.

To date: probable cases are 16% of confirmed cases.
Today: probable cases are 33% of confirmed cases. Confirmed + probable cases at just under 3.0k/day.
To get to... 
150k cases in 30 days: 5k cases/day average.
250k: 8.3k cases/day average
350k: 11.7k cases/day average
If cases stay relatively flat at ~3k/day or decline, there will be <=~90k cases for April and thus <150k.
In the fall, doubling time for cases/day was about 3.5 weeks. I would expect at most similar case growth now because of the combined effects of both strong downward forces (seasonality, natural immunity, vaccination) and strong upward forces (the state opening up, more risky behavior following vaccination, and B.1.1.7, which is expected to become dominant in Texas over the coming weeks).
If cases start increasing now like they did in the fall (or as they declined in the spring), confirmed + probable cases will be at ~6k/day by Around April 21, ~7.5k by end of April. I would expect this to be an approximate upper bound. Such a scenario would put the number of cases between 150k and 250k.
I expect cases to start growing soon in Texas, in line with the experiences of other states as B.1.1.7 becomes dominant.
Note that the State of Texas website numbers are *very* different from numbers available from other sources.
I like the sliders for the answers ...

Texas population 29M.
Texas cases to date (3/23) 2.76M. Figure actual cases ~4 * 2.76M = ~11M = ~38%.
To date, ~22.3% of Texas population has received at least one dose of vaccine.
So ~50% have some immunity (expected overlap between vaccinated and previously infected); ballpark 60% may have ~90% immunity by end of April, some small percentage with only one dose vaccine.
Few cases last April.
Nicer weather in April than in summer; many people may be outside.
But, Texas is completely "open." It's been open for 12 days.
And B.1.1.7 is likely to become the dominant strain in Texas by the end of March (https://cbsaustin.com/news/local/uk-variant-set-to-become-dominant-variant-in-texas-us-by-end-of-march), although the vaccines are largely effective against B.1.1.7.
Currently, curve (cases/day) is almost flat and at ~4k cases/day. 
Based on fall rise, average cases/day not likely to rise to more than ~6.5k cases/day, although greater levels are possible with B.1.1.7.
To have 150k cases in 30 days: 5k cases/day average.
250k: 8.3k cases/day
350k: 11.7k cases/day
So: if cases stay relatively flat, then April will have <150k cases.
If cases start to increase a bit, April will have 150k to 250k cases.
Cases would have to increase massively to have 250k to 350k cases. I don't think that's likely to happen given immunity levels and seasonality, even with the state completely "open" and B.1.1.7.
Some modeling for part of the state: https://www.utsouthwestern.edu/covid-19/assets/modeling.pdf
Rt in Texas: https://covidestim.org/us/TX
Rt in Texas currently est. 0.51, albeit with a wide margin of error. Based on other graphs I've seen, I'd say it's closer to 0.9. Even if it's 0.95 now, Rt won't exceed ~1.45 in April (worst case scenario).
The 7 day moving average of cases/day has been <5k since March 10, but we're right up against the edge of that forecast bin.
But if half moving to 90% of cases are B.1.1.7 in Texas in April, cases may increase more quickly.
If cases/day at 4k/day at beginning of April, roughly speaking, would have to get above 6k/day by end of April to exceed 150k total cases. That wouldn't be too hard; greater drops and rises happened last summer and early fall.
So, it's a tough call, but I think given B.1.1.7's contagiousness and Texas' openness, a bit of an uptick in cases can be anticipated primarily among the unvaccinated and those who haven't had Covid yet, as has been seen in other countries earlier.
The trend is downward. Vaccinations aren't going to eliminate the problem but will certainly deter the spread of the virus.

Using the case numbers from the Excel sheet linked in the question: ( https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/TexasCOVID19CaseCountData.xlsx ) The total cases for the thirty days February 20-March 21st is 143,650, or Bucket 1. The average daily cases for the last 21 days, March 1st-21st is 4,174.  Times 30 days, that's 125,220, or Bucket 1. The average daily cases for the last 14 days, March 8th-21st, is 3,726.64. Times 30 days, that's 111,799, or Bucket 1. The average daily cases for the last 7 days, March 15th-21st, is 3,505.71. Times 30 days, that's 105,171, or Bucket 1. I am accordingly increasing my confidence that April will be under 150,000 cases.

For my last forecast, I estimated a trend for the next weeks on the basis of data of the prior three months. Using the same calculation steps, but instead looking only at the trend of the last 10 days with (1) increased vaccination rates, (2) decreased infection rate and (3) the overall number of persons with antibodies (from vaccine + former infection) rising quicker than expected, the r-value did not rise due to the new variants but in fact shrank further below 1. The number of hotspots in the state dropped as well. With (a) fewer people who can potentially be infected and (b) fewer people actually spreading, the total expected cases dropped steeply to an approximate 140,000. Only if vaccination efforts should suddenly stop or the infection rate rise sharply (to at least 15,000 daily cases), could my previous forecast become true. It is therefore highly unlikely.
Although vaccine take-up in Texas is fairly slow, I think that the R being below 0.9 means that under 150k is very likely.

College spring break "peak weeks" are supposedly around now (mid-March). (https://www.springbreak.com/Spring_Break_Dates.html)   ..Generally assuming that the majority of spring breakers currently in TX who go on to test positive will more likely do so in other states, and possibly around the end of March/beginning of April. (https://www.cnn.com/videos/health/2021/03/15/coronavirus-spring-break-travel-vaccine-pandemic-walker-pkg-vpx.cnn) No significant change to the forecast for now. Texas is averaging about 4,313 total cases per day (incl. 'probable cases') through the first 15 days of March. (https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83)

Rt for TX is 0.84 according to https://covidactnow.org/?s=1669601.  I don't think the April total will be anywhere near 150k.  If the lowest bracket were "Fewer than 75,000" I wouldn't go all in, but I would still bet heavily on it. It's true that Texas politicians have made an issue of removing restrictions.  But the numbers have been going down sharply for two weeks now.  I'll ignore the chatter and bet on the trend.
Even with really lax policies, Texas and Florida continue to see falling cases and now weather is warming up while vaccine rollout is proceeding.
Zipping up and down, but about 5k per day now which is the threshold for bin 2
Cases roughly 4700 per day. Would put the next month at around 141,000. However, April is a long way away, and vaccines are continuing to be rolled out. Leaving it for now.

Average is now 4.7k per day which is into Bin 1
But April is a way away yet, with Easter to come.  Case rate is flattening off so deaths likely to follow that in April with 4 week delay.
Leaving forecast for now.

Texas is averaging about 4,548 new + probable cases per day for the 11 days of March so far. If this average were to be maintained for the 30 days of April approx. 136,448 confirmed plus probable cases would be the estimated total for that month. An average of 5000 such cases/day would equal 150,000 over 30 days. (FWIW, Texas has exceed 5000 total cases on four days in March so far.)(https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83) Texas currently remains one of the worst states for "total doses administered rate per 100K"; only three states are lower on this vaccination measure at the moment. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations) 
Also: https://www.fox4news.com/news/texas-to-receive-800000-covid-19-vaccine-doses-next-week-which-is-a-drop-from-this-week Right now it seems plausible that Texas could have issues with keeping cases below a total of 150,000 in April, but the March numbers so far would be below that threshold, if maintained.

April will likely bring a spike in confirmed and probable cases if Texans follow the lead of their governor and throw caution to the wind regarding the continued wearing of masks.  This question wouldn't need to be asked had there been strict adherence to and adoption of mask wearing and social distancing promoted by senior government officials from the outset.  Vaccination rates are improving across the board; however, there is a multi-week lag between receiving the first dose and second dose and a subsequent two week lag before the second dose max efficacy is achieved.  Variant B.1.1.7 (U.K.) infections are currently being confirmed as an increasing percentage of new infections and have been detected in over 50% of Houston area wastewater treatment samples as of early February.  Although the rate of new infections is trending downward Texas appears to be preemptively seizing defeat from the jaws of victory by removing restrictions on public health and safety measures before the virus has truly been stamped out from circulating populations.  While infections may rise before ultimately falling to near zero once the vast majority of the population has been vaccinated, fatalities should continue to decline as once overburdened healthcare facilities and beleaguered front line health care workers are more effectively able to treat seriously ill COVID patients following the winter surge. If the majority of Texans had already received their second dose as of today it would be reasonable to conclude that April would bring fewer than 150K new confirmed and probable cases and likely even fewer than 50,000.  Putting the burden of "personal responsibility" on a populace who is already tired and ready to move on from COVID restrictions hoping to return to a more "normal" pre-COVID lifestyle is detrimental to public health and safety.  As the data shows from other significantly smaller countries with greater population density than most US states (e.g. Taiwan, Vietnam) adherence to simple things like mask wearing drastically curtails the transmission of COVID-19.  Consider population density and geography relative to the U.S. four most populous states CA, TX, FL, NY respectively. Estimated population 2020 / Land in sq. miles (2010) / Population density per sq mile (2010)
CA:  39.4M / 155,779 sq mi / 239.1 p/sm
TX:  29.4M / 261,231 sq mi / 96.3 p/sm
FL:   21.7M / 53,624 sq mi / 350.6 p/sm
NY:  19.3M / 47,126 sq mi / 411.2 p/sm Number of confirmed COVID-19 infections / infections per 1,000,000 / infections % total population 
CA:  3.6M total infections / 91,412 / 9.13% infection rate among all Californians
TX:  2.71M total infections / 93,507 / 9.22% infection rate among all Texans
FL:  1.98M total infections / 91,145 / 9.12% infection rate among all Floridians
NY:  1.72M total infections / 88,439 / 8.91% infection rate among all New Yorkers Texas though the least densely populated of the top 4 states has the highest rate of infection per million at 93,507 and the highest percentage rate of infection among its residents (9.22%).  NY with greater than 4X the population density of TX trails with 88,439 infections per million and a 8.91% infection rate among its residents.  Draw what conclusions you will from this loose association of data but based on this info alone it would appear that Texans are going out of their way to infect one another by rejecting public health and safety measures. If we were to look at the same data regarding the top two most infections States by number of infections per 1,000,000 residents (North Dakota and South Dakota) it becomes even more glaringly obvious that masks and social distancing measures improve public health and help curtail the transmission of COVID. Estimated population 2020 / Land in sq. miles (2010) / Population density per sq mile (2010)
ND:  762K / 69K sq mi / 9.7 p/sm
SD:  885K / 76K sq mi / 10.7 p/sm Number of confirmed COVID-19 infections / infections per 1,000,000 / infections % total population 
ND:  101K total infections / 132K infections per Million residents / 17.32% among all North Dakotans
SD:  114K total infections / 129K infections per Million residents / 12.88% among all South Dakotans Conclude what you will but I'm pretty sure infections in TX aren't going to magically drop off now that the Governor has announced that we've beat COVID.  This sounds like a tune we've heard once or twice before.
Restrictions lifted but also increased vaccine rollout.

Ref rationale on previous forecast https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1243300
Think I read the bins wrong, if 7k per day is 210k then should have been forecasting bin 2 not 3. Rates are dropping (latest is 6k per day) so more likely to be lower, but still not convinced will drop below 150k for April the end of which is a month away.   Looking out for any potential case increases following lifting of restrictions but this this is still a week away to show in the data.  I.e. takes a couple of weeks for COVID to show up, a bit of time to spread and then a bit of delay time in getting reported, so any uptick in cases should start to show 2 to 3 weeks after restrictions lifted - if it is going to happen.

The current daily rate is around 6000.  Texas has just opened fully for business.  It will be late march when they admit that reopening was a mistake and the infection rates will soar.  By mid April, it will get back under control somewhat around the 6000 per day level.  Assuming an average of 6000 per day for the entire 31 day month, is around 181,000

Texas has by far the highest test positivity rate in the U.S. and they test nefariously little at the moment. A situation similar to June 2020 may occur, where more testing reveals more cases at a high or even increasing positivity. Add the reopening and an end to mandating masks by Mr Abbott, and the spread of more contagious variants plus maybe travel (spring break) and crowded beaches to the brew, and the hurricane Mr. Osterholm was talking about, will likely move right into Texas, silently but violently.

Per a recent CDC study, masks reduce the spread of Covid over 100 days by.... 1.32%. of course, not everyone is using them properly, but the difference between policy and no policy is 1.32%. https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/pdfs/mm7010e3-H.pdf

The new variants of the virus have arrived in Texas (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/health/coronavirus-variant-tracker.html) and are likely to increase the R-number (https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55507012) well above r=1 (https://epiforecasts.io/covid/posts/subnational/united-states/texas/) resulting in a third wave. The wave will be reduced by the overall number of persons immune to the virus through vaccinations and past infections, while assuming both are effective against mutations. Still, it is likely that with the lifting of measures more hotspots will emerge in Texas as was the case in the past (e.g. when bars were opened in El Paso and a wave of infections followed https://www.texastribune.org/2020/07/31/coronavirus-timeline-texas/).
With those thoughts in mind, I calculated app. 485,000 infections for April 2021.

Potential factor: Texas is currently the worst state in vaccine "total delivered per 100,000 population", and one of the worst for "total doses administered per 100K" per this source: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations

Cases currently are at 6,192/day.  This is equal to 186k in April. Vaccine will tend to push cases down.  But Texas reopening will tend to push cases up. Think most likely is that cases continue to fall to below the 150k/month threshold, but staying constant, or even increasing are not impossible. Very unlikely that they increase higher than 350k.

10k per day is 300k for April. Currently daily rate is about 6k to 8k per day.  If we calculated 7k per day this is 210k over April. The 150k threshold for bin 2 is 5k cases per day.
The 250k threshold for bin 3 is 8.3k cases per day.   We are still only in March so plenty of time for the average to move from where it is. 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#compare-trends_newcases With an ease in restrictions expect rates to increase a little.   https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/09/01/816707182/map-tracking-the-spread-of-the-coronavirus-in-the-u-s?t=1615117778396 Cases should go up about 2 to 3 weeks from now, so late March.  If they spiral they will then take off, but need to see data for this.
Widening forecast to cover the 210k to 300k range.

1) The elimination of state-imposed penalties is not the same as a transformation in behavior. Every store I passed by today still has their mask signs up. 2) The last two weeks' new case rate from the Excel file (confirmed and probable), extrapolated to 30 days, would be 177,268 new cases, which is to say, the low third of bucket #2. 3) Seasonality effects, more people immune because they already had cases, and more people immune due to vaccinations are all likely to reduce spread compared to the last two weeks. Maybe things will look different in a week or two, sure, but that's where I am now.

According to covidactnow the reinfection rate for TX is currently 1.00, implying a constant rate of new infections.  https://covidactnow.org/?s=1646585 ICU's in TX are 82% occupied, so it won't take much of an increase to create a bad situation.  Presumably politicians want to avoid this.  https://covidactnow.org/us/texas-tx/?s=1646585 The population having received at least one dose of vaccine is 23.55%.  https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/?sref=x7nYEkiY
By the end of March somewhere approaching 40% of the population should have been vaccinated with at least one shot. Unless Texans have some kind of death wish, and insist on going to packed bars and avoid wearing masks, 40% partial herd immunity should permit the reinfection rate to fall below 0.9.  And new infections should be under 5k/day for the month of April.  We watch and wait.

I expect it to be roughly what it is now which I believe is about 5500 new cases per day in TX (with much variability).  As people get outside more in spring, covid will tend to drop and perhaps offset the risk due to mask non-use.  Additionally... many people will still wear masks.
i was using an unbiased website for my numbers...  which are just a bit higher then what tx puts out... lol.  adjusted down since it is the site we are going by.

10k per day is 300k for April. Currently daily rate is about 6k to 8k per day.  If we calculated 7k per day this is 210k over April
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#compare-trends_newcases Rates have been dropping, but with restrictions easing expectation is they will increase.  Cases should go up about 2 to 3 week from now, so late March.  If they spiral they will then take off, but need to see data for this.
Going to put parameters around the 300k mark for now

Looking at their dashboard it looks like confirmed and probably are somewhere around 6.5k cases a day right now.  If the month of April averaged 6.5 cases a day that would be 195k cases. If cases were to jump up to double it would be 390. I think in April the vaccine will be taking more effect, so I see doubling as an unlikely worst case. I think it's likely that cases remain pretty steady going forward, maybe some ups and downs but I think vaccinations and the potential effect of warmer temps will counteract the effect of reopening to some extent. There's also a good chance cases continue downward in Texas by April.

Per the source provided confirmed TX cases significantly declined in January and Feb. 2021, with a small "rebound" (upward) reported over the last several days. 'Probable' cases generally have followed the same trend. ..Will follow the data through March to get a better idea. The first five days of March are averaging about 5,665 total plus probable cases per day, with a high count of 8,361 and a low of 1,944.  As one possibility the current (early March) average of 5,665 times 30 days (In April) might result in about 170,000 total cases (confirmed + probable), if maintained. Texas recently was reported to have "...some of the lowest per capita vaccine distribution numbers". This measure will also need to be watched. (https://www.wfaa.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/texas-low-vaccine-distribution-per-capita-us-state/287-701d0b86-dafe-408e-9d0c-502fdb200f62, https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations) FWIW, Texas Gov. I just realized this is a prediction for the month of april, not the month of march. So I am revising downward. Total of 5903 cases confirmed and probable for 03/04. Times 30 days in April gives a maximum of 177,000 cases. as I expect a decline, I think it's highly likely we will be under 150,000. I pretty much nailed my last three covid forecasts so I'm pretty confident with this.

It seems pretty clear that lockdowns and mask wearing have little effect on this virus. I don't expect Texas's change in policy to have a negative effect. As one of many examples, just compare Florida to California. California is one of the states that is  youngest as far as median age, and they have very strict lockdown measures. Florida is one of the oldest states in terms of median age and has had a very open policy. There is some mask wearing, but all businesses are open and tourism is high. Disney world is open in Florida but Disneyland in California is closed. Based on the fact that this virus has literally a 1000 fold greater effect on older people, you would expect that Florida would have literally 100 times the cases but they are about the same as California.  I believe the drop since December has mostly been the result of the virus following the flu season trend, and also a result of the CDC's policy change in December regarding PCR testing. they stated they do not recommend PCR tests above about 32 cycles, which I think eliminated a lot of the false positives. Before December we probably had 20% to 40% of cases which were false positives because of high PCR cycling. World renowned epidemiologists are also stating that the reason we have so many flu cases is that most of our flu cases are being diagnosed as covid, which is another reason to think this will tend to follow the flu season curve. I expect Texas cases to level off and slightly decline over this month.
